title: Physical pendulum - linear density for triangle

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A pendulum is made from an object of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> in the shape of a narrow triangle of height <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The object hangs vertically from a pivot point located at the top vertex of the triangle. The mass of the object is uniformly distributed across the object’s area and can be modeled as a linear mass density <math alttext="lambda equals c y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>y</mi></math>, where <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>c</mi></math> is a positive constant and <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> is the distance from the pivot to locations on the object. (a)i. Derive an expression for the period of the object when undergoing small oscillations about the pivot point. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

The second object has the same mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, which, as in the first object, is uniformly distributed over the object’s area. A pivot point is located a distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> above the second object’s center of mass, where <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> is the distance between the original object’s center of mass and its pivot point.ii. Indicate whether the oscillation period of the second object is longer than, shorter than, or the same as the period of the original object. Justify your answer.

Reminder: Each object has the same mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and each pivot is the same distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> above the center of mass.(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="I sub P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> in terms of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, <math alttext="I sub P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math>, <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
